--- title: "Getting to know your data" author: "Claus O. Wilke" date: last-modified format: revealjs: theme: - default - Wilke-theme.scss auto-stretch: false chalkboard: true execute: fig-format: svg fig-asp: 0.618 fig-width: 5.5 --- ## Any data analysis should start with basic quality control ::: {.fragment} 1. Assess data relevance (Can the data answer your question in principle?) ::: ::: {.fragment} 2. Assess data provenance (Where does the data come from? Is it reliable?) ::: ::: {.fragment} 3. Clean data if required (In practice, this is 70-80% of data analysis work) ::: ::: {.fragment} 4. Perform descriptive analysis and sanity checks (Inspect summary statistics, distributions, scatter plots, etc.) ::: ## Components of data quality :::: {.columns .small-font} ::: {.column width="30%"} •  Accuracy •  Precision •  Usability •  Completeness •  Consistency •  Accessibility •  Relevance ::: ::: {.column width="70%"}   ::: :::: ## Components of data quality :::: {.columns .small-font} ::: {.column width="30%"} [•  Accuracy]{.highlight} •  Precision •  Usability •  Completeness •  Consistency •  Accessibility •  Relevance ::: ::: {.column width="70%"} [Does the data contain any systematic errors or biases?]{.highlight} ::: :::: ## Components of data quality :::: {.columns .small-font} ::: {.column width="30%"} •  Accuracy [•  Precision]{.highlight} •  Usability •  Completeness •  Consistency •  Accessibility •  Relevance ::: ::: {.column width="70%"} Does the data contain any systematic errors or biases? [How affected are observations by random errors/noise?]{.highlight} ::: :::: ## Accuracy means low bias, precision means low noise ![](../assets/know-your-data/accuracy-precision.svg){.absolute top="10%" left="15%" width="60%"} ## Components of data quality :::: {.columns .small-font} ::: {.column width="30%"} •  Accuracy •  Precision [•  Usability]{.highlight} •  Completeness •  Consistency •  Accessibility •  Relevance ::: ::: {.column width="70%"} Does the data contain any systematic errors or biases? How affected are observations by random errors/noise? [Is the data documented? Is it machine-readable?]{.highlight} ::: :::: ## Usability requires a data dictionary :::{.fragment .move-down-1em} **Data Dictionary**
A "centralized repository of information about data such as meaning, relationships to other data, origin, usage, and format" ([Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_dictionary)) ::: :::{.fragment .move-down-1em} Example: [Palmer penguins reference page](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/reference/penguins.html) ::: ## Components of data quality :::: {.columns .small-font} ::: {.column width="30%"} •  Accuracy •  Precision •  Usability [•  Completeness]{.highlight} •  Consistency •  Accessibility •  Relevance ::: ::: {.column width="70%"} Does the data contain any systematic errors or biases? How affected are observations by random errors/noise? Is the data documented? Is it machine-readable? [Are entire records missing? Are observations missing?]{.highlight} ::: :::: ## Components of data quality :::: {.columns .small-font} ::: {.column width="30%"} •  Accuracy •  Precision •  Usability •  Completeness [•  Consistency]{.highlight} •  Accessibility •  Relevance ::: ::: {.column width="70%"} Does the data contain any systematic errors or biases? How affected are observations by random errors/noise? Is the data documented? Is it machine-readable? Are entire records missing? Are observations missing? [Does data vary among sources or over time?]{.highlight} ::: :::: ## Components of data quality :::: {.columns .small-font} ::: {.column width="30%"} •  Accuracy •  Precision •  Usability •  Completeness •  Consistency [•  Accessibility]{.highlight} •  Relevance ::: ::: {.column width="70%"} Does the data contain any systematic errors or biases? How affected are observations by random errors/noise? Is the data documented? Is it machine-readable? Are entire records missing? Are observations missing? Does data vary among sources or over time? [Do you have access to the data? Can you obtain it?]{.highlight} ::: :::: ## Components of data quality :::: {.columns .small-font} ::: {.column width="30%"} •  Accuracy •  Precision •  Usability •  Completeness •  Consistency •  Accessibility [•  Relevance]{.highlight} ::: ::: {.column width="70%"} Does the data contain any systematic errors or biases? How affected are observations by random errors/noise? Is the data documented? Is it machine-readable? Are entire records missing? Are observations missing? Does data vary among sources or over time? Do you have access to the data? Can you obtain it? [Can you use the data to address your question?]{.highlight} ::: :::: # Inspecting and cleaning a dataset in R ## The dataset: Births in NC :::: {.columns} ::: {.fragment .column .smaller-font width="50%"} **Details and Source**
This dataset contains data on a sample of 1450 birth records from 2001 that statistician John Holcomb at Cleveland State University selected from the North Carolina State Center for Health and Environmental Statistics. The dataset has 1450 observations on 15 variables. ::: ::: {.fragment .column .xtiny-font .move-up-4em width="50%"} Variable | Description --------: | :-------------- `ID` | Patient ID code `Plural` | `1`=single birth, `2`=twins, `3`=triplets `Sex` | Sex of the baby: `1`=male `2`=female `MomAge` | Mother's age (in years) `Weeks` | Completed weeks of gestation `Marital` | Marital status: `1`=married or `2`=not married `RaceMom` | Mother's race: `1`=white, `2`=black, `3`=American Indian, `4`=Chinese, `5`=Japanese, `6`=Hawaiian, `7`=Filipino, or `8`=Other Asian or Pacific Islander `HispMom` | Hispanic origin of mother: `C`=Cuban, `M`=Mexican, `N`=not Hispanic, `O`=Other Hispanic, `P`=Puerto Rico, `S`=Central/South America `Gained` | Weight gained during pregnancy (in pounds) `Smoke` | Smoker mom? `1`=yes or `0`=no `BirthWeightOz` | Birth weight in ounces `BirthWeightGm` | Birth weight in grams `Low` | Indicator for low birth weight: `1`=2500 grams or less `Premie` | Indicator for premature birth: `1`=36 weeks or sooner `MomRace` | Mother's race: `black`, `hispanic`, `other`, or `white` ::: :::: ## Start with a cursory inspection ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.fragment .tiny-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} NCbirths <- read_csv("https://wilkelab.org/DSC385/datasets/NCbirths.csv") NCbirths ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1,450 × 15 ID Plural Sex MomAge of every variable against every other variable ::: # Working with missing values in R ## R propagates missingness ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- c(1, 2, NA, 4) sum(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] NA ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .move-down-1em} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mean(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] NA ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .move-down-1em} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x == 2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] FALSE TRUE NA FALSE ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Many functions allow explicit exclusion of `NA` values ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- c(1, 2, NA, 4) sum(x, na.rm = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 7 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .move-down-1em} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mean(x, na.rm = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2.333333 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .move-down-1em} But is this the right thing to do? ::: ## There is no general right or wrong approach ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- c(2, 1, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 2, NA, 1, 2, 1, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 2) mean(x, na.rm = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1.352941 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .move-down-1em} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- c(NA, NA, NA, 2, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, 1, NA, NA, NA, NA) mean(x, na.rm = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1.5 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .move-down-1em} R's default is conservative: If there's at least one `NA`, the result is `NA` ::: ## We need to use `is.na()` to check for missing values ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} c(1, 2, NA, 4) == NA # does not work ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] NA NA NA NA ``` ::: ::: ::: {.move-down-1em} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} is.na(c(1, 2, NA, 4)) # works ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] FALSE FALSE TRUE FALSE ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Replacing `NA` values with something else Remember from class on data wrangling: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} band_data <- full_join(band_members, band_instruments) band_data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 × 3 name band plays 1 Mick Stones 2 John Beatles guitar 3 Paul Beatles bass 4 Keith guitar ``` ::: ::: ## Replacing `NA` values with something else Replace `NA`s with empty strings in `plays` column: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} band_data |> mutate(plays = replace_na(plays, "")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 × 3 name band plays 1 Mick Stones "" 2 John Beatles "guitar" 3 Paul Beatles "bass" 4 Keith "guitar" ``` ::: ::: ## Replacing `NA` values with something else Replace `NA`s with empty strings in all columns: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} band_data |> mutate(across(everything(), ~replace_na(.x, ""))) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 × 3 name band plays 1 Mick "Stones" "" 2 John "Beatles" "guitar" 3 Paul "Beatles" "bass" 4 Keith "" "guitar" ``` ::: ::: ## Replacing things with `NA` values Replace empty strings with `NA` in `plays` column (requires **naniar** package): ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} band_data |> mutate(across(everything(), ~replace_na(.x, ""))) |> replace_with_na_at("plays", ~.x == "") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 × 3 name band plays 1 Mick "Stones" 2 John "Beatles" guitar 3 Paul "Beatles" bass 4 Keith "" guitar ``` ::: ::: ## Replacing things with `NA` values Replace empty strings with `NA` in all columns (requires **naniar** package): ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} band_data |> mutate(across(everything(), ~replace_na(.x, ""))) |> replace_with_na_all(~.x == "") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 × 3 name band plays 1 Mick Stones 2 John Beatles guitar 3 Paul Beatles bass 4 Keith guitar ``` ::: ::: ## Removing rows with `NA` values Remove all rows with any `NA`s with `na.omit()`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} band_data |> na.omit() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 × 3 name band plays 1 John Beatles guitar 2 Paul Beatles bass ``` ::: ::: ## Removing rows with `NA` values Remove all rows where specific columns contain `NA`s: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} band_data |> filter(!is.na(plays)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 3 name band plays 1 John Beatles guitar 2 Paul Beatles bass 3 Keith guitar ``` ::: ::: ## Removing rows with `NA` values Conversely: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} band_data |> filter(is.na(plays)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 × 3 name band plays 1 Mick Stones ``` ::: ::: ## Visualizing `NA`s ::: {.small-font} By default, missing points are not shown ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(NCbirths) + aes(Weeks, Gained) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![ ](know-your-data_files/figure-revealjs/NCbirths-plot-missing-1.svg){width=50%} ::: ::: ::: ## Visualizing `NA`s ::: {.small-font} Can show them with the **naniar** package ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(naniar) ggplot(NCbirths) + aes(Weeks, Gained) + geom_miss_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![ ](know-your-data_files/figure-revealjs/NCbirths-plot-missing2-1.svg){width=50%} ::: ::: ::: ## Further reading - Wikipedia: [Data dictionary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_dictionary) - <script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
